awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of a novel technology to manufacture animal-free muscle proteins in bacteria and yeasts
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project includes improved food security, environmental benefits, and human health benefits.  This project will develop a meat alternative that more closely mimics the taste and texture of animal meat.  The technology developed from the proposed project will be used to build a vertically integrated food manufacturing platform that can withstand supply chain disruptions from natural disasters and pandemics. These meat alternatives will reduce and replace traditional meat consumption, with many environmental benefits - lowered greenhouse gas emissions and aquatic pollution; lower use of energy, water and land; and reduced antibiotics usage. There are benefits to human health for reduced meat consumption. Furthermore, production costs will be eventually be comparable to that of mushroom farming.

The proposed project aims to develop a fermentation-based meat alternative that more closely mimics the taste and texture of animal meal through recombinant protein technologies.  Additionally, the project aims to leverage the texture and flavor of mushroom mycelia, and supplement this with recombinant muscle proteins to further enhance the taste and nutritional profiles and overcome many of the shortcomings of existing plant-based meat products. To date the concept of combining recombinant muscle protein and single cell protein is novel and has not been reported. Large gaps persist between plant-based and lab-grown meat, with regards to cost and consumer experience. Plant-based meat is more affordable but faces consumer resistance due to sub-optimal texture and nutritional profiles, while cultivated meat offers a consumer experience similar to that of animal meat but at a much higher cost. Towards this goal, muscle protein genes will be expressed in a microbial host and enzymatically cross-linked with vegetable protein to produce protein fibers that can be formulated into synthetic meat. The technical objectives also include demonstration the feasibility of crosslinking muscle fiber proteins extracted from meat with mycoprotein from mushroom to produce desired textural and flavor properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Meat has been consumed by humans for millennia even though raising animals for food is both resource intensive and environmentally unfriendly. Recent consumer trends have shifted to meat alternatives driven by health, and environmental concerns. As a result, there is a plethora of plant-based meat alternative products on the market, however most of them are limited to ground meat type of products such as hamburger and nuggets. The taste and texture are still suboptimal and present challenges for consumer adoption of these sustainable products. Additionally, these products require the usage of texture additives/binding agent such as methylcellulose, which is indigestible and could cause health concerns. Another potential solution to the above-mentioned impacts of animal agriculture is lab grown cultured meat, consisting of muscle tissues grown via in-vitro cell culture and harvested for human consumption. The taste, flavor, and texture of lab grown meat is similar to animal meat, but there are many challenges facing the use of this technology including the need for expensive growth media, the slow growth of mammalian cells, and general scalability issues.

To overcome these challenges, we proposed to use an innovative approach using recombinant muscle proteins to improve the texture and taste of our meat alternatives. If successful, our technology will overcome the textural and taste limitations of these products while achieving similar reduction in environmental impacts and enhanced nutritional values. Our technology is animal-free, which eliminates animal-human interactions and could reduce the occurrence of zoonotic pandemics. 

As demonstrated in a separate phase I research report, we have successfully identified that the recombinant muscle proteins (FW) can mimic the meaty texture. Another function of the FW is a protein-based binding agent that can replace current texturizing additives such as methylcellulose. This paves the foundation for commercializing our technology and progressing into the next steps of our R&D efforts.

 


Last Modified: 06/08/2022
Modified by: Chenfeng Lu

Image
  • Animal free nuggets made with FW protein.
    BIV team
    Copyrighted
    Chenfeng Lu
    Prototype
